results.title: Genre
results.brief_description:
A short created by a student for the 2004 ACMI Diegesis secondary school media festival.
A day in the life of a blocked screenwriter. A film producer is harassing a screenwriter who is suffering major problems trying to come up with a script for his next movie. This short film visually depicts the film scenarios this writer conjures up - a mystery and gangster style thriller. Neither of these stories satisfy the frustrated screenwriter, and so he ends up writing a simple love story between two ordinary people. Finally he finishes the script and rushes to the post box to send his script to the producer. Upon arriving at the letter box, he meets the woman of his dreams. His screenwriting dreams become a reality.

group_siblings.title: Attack of the strange insects from Uranus

results.title: Genius: Leonardo Da Vinci
results.brief_description: The brilliance and legacy left by Renaissance man, Leonardo Da Vinci, as thinker, sculptor, painter, engineer and inventor, lives on today. One of the most important figures in modern history, Da Vinci not only achieved legendary status within his own lifetime with his work, but was also to influence the future of both science and art. Freed from the constraints of Medieval culture, Da Vinci had free reign to explore and develop his ideas. He had very intense interests with solutions that challenged the scientific notions of the day in anatomy, engineering and architecture. Whilst reviving the nature of ‘true scientific discovery’, he opened up ‘observation’ as a method of scientific and medical discovery. A cross-disciplinary figure of epic proportions, whose legacy has seeped into the public consciousness and includes such inventions as: the clock (with arms for minutes and hours), camera obscura, the system of gears, cogs and weights to name only a few. Aided by 3-D graphics, this documentary explores the complexities and insights that shaped Da Vinci’s work.

results.title: Genius: Charles Darwin
results.brief_description: Charles Darwin has been dubbed by many as the most important figure in the 20th Century. Due to the encouragement from fellow student John Henslow, Darwin joined the HMS Beagle as the ship’s naturalist, surveying the voyage and recording data for a period of 5 years as the ship travelled the world including the Galapagos Islands. It is from here that Darwin’s “Origins of the Species” was developed and written, although published 20 years later. This documentary details Darwin’s reclusive lifestyle at his famous home in Kent, ‘The Down House’, and the partnership he had with wife Emma Wedgewood, also first cousin. The tragedy of his ill children possibly due to in-breeding, but more broadly how the intimate relationship with his family directed the path of his career. Regular visitors to ‘The Down House’ included Sir Charles Lyle and Sir Joseph Hooker. It was Lyle’s work on geology - ‘gradual but persistent change’ - that proved a catalyst for Darwin’s theory of evolution. Broadly discussed is how Darwin’s theories were to affect a century of thought and religious debate and remind us in the advent of genetic engineering and cloning, how relevant Darwinism and Neo-Darwinism are in contemporary moral and intellectual debate.

results.title: Genghis Khan = Cheng Ji Si Khan
results.creator_credit: Zhan Xiangchi, Youth Film Studio and Inner Mongolia Film Studio
results.brief_description:
This is a biography and historical epic of the Mongol empire leader, Genghis Khan. In the 12th century, nomadic tribes on the Mongol Steppe were at war, and the Kiyans defeated the Tatars. The Kiyan chief named his new-born son, Temujin, who later became the emperor of one of the most powerful empires of all time—Genghis Khan. When Temujin was 13, his father was poisoned to death by his enemy, the Tatars. The Kiyan tribe collapsed and Temujin narrowly escaped from being killed. Temujin became a hero of the Kiyans and was ambitious to restore the glory of the tribe. Temujin made alliance with the Kereyid tribe and won support from the powerful Jadaran tribe. The alliance defeated the Merikids and Temujin consolidated his power. The rise of Temujin’s tribe became a threat to the Jadarans, who united some thirteen smaller tribes to attack Temujin. Facing the powerful enemy, Temujin ordered a retreat of his troops and avoided a fight. The Jadarans killed a lot innocent people and lost the support of other tribes. Temujin gathered all the forces he could and defeated the Tatars. Temujin pardoned the Tatars and sent a Tatar girl, Namulun to the Kereyid chief so as to distance the Kereyid chief and his son. The Kereyids plotted to assassinate Temujin, who managed to escape thanks to Namulun. Temujin had a decisive battle with the Kereyids and totally defeated them. Temujin united the tribes on the Mongol Steppe and became Genghis Khan.

Genghis Khan was the founder of the powerful Mongol Empire in the 12th century. After Genghis Khan’s death, the empire became the largest contiguous empire in history under the rule of Kublai Khan. This 3-hour epic film has its setting on the Mongolia Steppe and features a lot of horse fighting scenes. Siqin Gaowa played Temujin’s mother in the film. Siqin Gaowa, originally Mongolian, is a very well-known Chinese-Swiss actress. She starred in films such as Luo Tuo Xiang Zi (1982), Xiang Hun Nu (aka. The Women from the Lake of Scented Souls, 1993) and many TV series.
The Inner Mongolia Film Studio was established in 1958, and produced many films and documentaries about local life and culture in Inner Mongolia before the 1990s. (4 stars - Yuxing Zhou; December 16, 2010)

results.title: Genevieve
results.brief_description: A captivating British comedy about two couples, classic-car enthusiasts, who, after participating in the annual London to Brighton rally challenge each other to a friendly race. Their playfulness becomes increasingly intense as they speed to the Westminster Bridge finish line. Larry Adler received an Academy Award nomination for his memorable harmonica score. Cast: Dinah Sheridan, John Gregson, Kay Kendall, Kenneth More, Geoffrey Keen, Reginald Beckwith, Arthur Wontner, Joyce Grenfell.

results.title: Genetics: past, present and future (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Rodger Jones, BBC-TV and Open University
results.brief_description: This film is concerned with the origin of the science of genetics and reconstructs some of the crucial experiments performed. It also shows how nowadays it is possible to produce entirely novel plants by manipulations that avoid sexual hybridisation. Introduced by Jonathon Hodge.

results.title: Genetics: Mendel's law
results.brief_description: Duplicates some of Mendel’s experiments with pea plants, and explains his laws of segregation, independent assortment and dominance. Describes later work by De Vries, Correns, Morgan and Muller. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Genetics and plant breeding
results.creator_credit: David Morphet, Peter Bradford, Unilever Films and World Wide Pictures
results.brief_description: Mendel’s laws of inheritance, and how the passage of the dominant and recessive characteristics from one generation to another depends on discrete particles of matter, particles which are now known to be genes on the chromosomes in the cell nucleus. It shows how the principles of genetics are applied to produce new varieties of plants.

results.title: Genetic responsibility: a father's part
results.brief_description: Can a father’s health and behaviour affect the health of his children? Although often overlooked because of a cultural blindspot, research is indicating that drug use, chemical therapies, cigarette smoking and environmental and occupational exposures in the father before and during conception can lead to problems during pregnancy, birth defects and childhood cancer. The evidence presented is startling and must be seriously considered. Suitable for Secondary and Tertiary level students.
